title: South Korea contemplates visa waiver for Chinese touristsTravelandtourworld.com
text:
South Korea contemplates visa waiver for Chinese tourists Published on : Tuesday, September 8, 2015
With the betterment of Seoulâ€™s economic and political ties with Beijing in recent years, a research has been started by South Korea into the possible introduction of visa waivers for Chinese nationals on a gradual basis.
The Foreign Ministry has asked a research centre affiliated with the International Organisation for Migration to write a report on the viability of possibly signing a visa waiver agreement with China for ordinary passport holders, a ministry official said.
The report will be submitted by the end of October.
South Korea maintains an agreement allowing holders of Chinese passports for diplomats and government officials to stay in South Korea for up to 30 days without an entry visa.
Notably, South Korea has continuously made efforts in recent years to relieve visa regulations for Chinese visitors, including visa waivers for Chinese travelers to Jeju Island, a southern resort island.
Critics say the introduction of visa waivers will help increase Chinese tourists, but still cautious about a possible rise in the number of illegal entries of North Korean agents as well as Chinese.
